Award.AwardTitle: The 2018 East Coast Operator Algebra Symposium
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the 2018 East Coast Operator Algebra Symposium that will be held on October 13 and 14, 2018, on the campus of Texas Christian University in Fort Worth, Texas. Additional information about this meeting can be found at the website: http://faculty.tcu.edu/jcarrion/ecoas2018/.

This conference is the sixteenth installment of the East Coast Operator Algebra Symposium (ECOAS), a series that annually brings together a diverse group of mathematicians with broad research interests in the theory of operator algebras, both C*-algebras and von Neumann algebras as well as noncommutative geometry. Some of the 2018 areas of emphasis will be on the following topics: the theory of subfactors, deformation/rigidity theory, free probabilty, classification of C*-algebras (the Elliott program), the C*-algebra approach to the Novikov conjecture, C*-algebras and dynamical systems, the Baum-Connes conjecture, noncommutative differential geometry, and index theory. The conference program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018 East Coast Operator Algebra Symposium (ECOAS) was hosted by Texas Christian University in Fort Worth, Texas. The dates for meeting were October 13 and 14 of 2018.

Speakers included experts from the areas of C^*-algebras, von Neumann algebras, and non-commutative geometry.  Most speakers were young researchers and postdocs, who spoke on recent trends and cutting-edge techniques in their fields.

The meeting featured eleven plenary speakers:

- Sarah Browne (Penn State)
- Kristin Courtney (WWU Münster)
- Marius Dadarlat (Purdue University)
- Rolando de Santiago (UCLA)
- Daniel Drimbe (University of Regina)
- James Gabe (University of Glasgow)
- Bin Gui (Rutgers University)
- Corey Jones (Australian National University)
- Xin Ma (Texas A&M)
- Jesse Peterson (Vanderbilt University)
- Rufus Willett (University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa)

Each of the speakers gave a 50-minute lecture.

The ECOAS conference series has several objectives. One is to help young researchers in the area of operator algebras broaden their acquaintance with the field. Another is to facilitate their interaction with senior researchers in operator algebra theory---among them possible future colleagues, mentors and collaborators. With these goals in mind, the ECOAS series places a heavy emphasis on attracting young researchers to the meetings and giving them opportunities to present their work and otherwise interact with established figures. In the conferences in the series so far, over half of the participants and a substantial number of the speakers have been students or postdoctoral fellows.

Demographic Information: There were 54 registered participants for the meeting, including the two organizers.  Here is a breakdown in terms of gender, ethnicity, and position (from self-reported data, which is incomplete):

Gender:

- Female – 8
- Male – 22

Ethnicity:

- Asian – 7
- Hispanic – 6
- White non-Hispanic – 15

Position:

- Faculty (tenured, tenure track, instructor) – 6
- Postdoctoral Fellow – 6
- Graduate Student – 15
- Undergraduate Student – 1


Last Modified: 04/01/2020
Modified by: Jose R Carrion Muniz
